column4: can anybody see an obvious reason my cron job doesn't seem to be going off?      0 */4 * * *     reporting source /etc/web/conf.d/stage2_loader_toolbar_reporting.env && /home/reporting/trunk/crons/stage3_loader_toolbar_reporting.sh 2>&1 | /usr/bin/logger -t stage3_loader_toolbar_reporting
im not using crontab -e im editing /etc/crontab directly
well, you need the full path to the executable as proper crontab syntax, I also beleive that crontab dissallows pipes
youre better off makin that a script and having cron execute the script
yeah i was trying to avoid that but i guess i'll have to do that again.
are you using the same keys for those machines or different keys with the same passphrase?
Same keys, id_rsa.pub is appended to authorized_keys on the remote machine.  so the user bob is using id_rsa.  IE ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa bill@example.com
and the same key is in the authorized_keys file for bill?
sorry, yes that is what i was saying, the id_rsa.pub is in bills authorized_keys
it is not in bob's authorized_keys, does it need to be there as well? I was just calling ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa
no, not unless you logging in as bob. However, bill must be allowed to log in remotely. Are you sure bill has remote login permission via ssh?

he does, i actually just tested the setup on my machien and it works fine, but another user is trying to do the same thing but it prompts him for his passphrase everytime even they he added it with ssh-add
so your all fine but from another machine and another user (mary) tries to ssh-add her private key and passphrase and cant log into bill@example?
they can login, but even after cacheing it with ssh-agent / ssh-add it still prompts them for their keys passphrase when it shouldn't be
make sure they arent using multiple private keys in ~.ssh. ssh-agent only loads the defaults
i'll check, who knows what craziness they did :)
they can use more than one but then ssh-agent needs to be told
FWIW, all my keys are passphraseless. I find that much easier to handle.
passphraseless is certainly more convenient but unfortunately not as secure if somehow the key is obtained by people that shouldn't have it :(
indeed. but, sysadmin is a fraught with comprimise. One must pick his battles.
ah truer words have never been spoken
